PRESIDENT’S MESSAGE On behalf of our entire community, I want to express my gratitude to members of the Northwestern University Leadership Circle (NULC) . Your generosity truly matters as our faculty, staff, and students join together to tackle—with determination and ingenuity—the formidable challenges facing our nation and world. In this report, we recognize the impact of donors who joined Mimi and me in making annual leadership gifts to the University between September , 1 2019 , and August , 31 2020 . The Leadership Circle includes thousands of alumni, parents, and friends whose annual gifts have fueled the extraordinary progress of We Will The Campaign for Northwestern . . We are tremendously proud of how the Campaign is advancing the University’s strategic priorities. At the same time, it is clear that the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, racial injustice, economic upheaval, and other critical issues challenge us to broaden our commitment to serve the greater good. In this report, we are proud to share stories that highlight the ways NULC donors empower our students and faculty to do pioneering work. You’ll meet scholarship recipient Mia Mamone ’ , who 21 has leveraged unique learning opportunities to embark on a career as a socially engaged journalist. We also introduce Pete Puleo ’ , a 19 PhD candidate in earth and planetary sciences whose research trips to the Arctic shed light on the causes of global climate change. Your philanthropy provides our faculty with resources to continue leading and innovating. We are pleased to feature Clyde Yancy, the Magerstadt Professor in the Feinberg School of Medicine, who has called attention to the disproportionate effects of COVID-19 on Black communities, while positioning Northwestern at the forefront of cardiology research and training physicians from diverse backgrounds. We also highlight Linda Darragh, a clinical professor of entrepreneurship in the Kellogg School of Management, who has launched a project that has helped alumni and students advise Evanston business owners during the pandemic. Especially now, the University’s ability to make a meaningful difference in the world is strengthened by the dedication of benefactors like you. We are grateful that so many Leadership Circle members also belong to NU Loyal, the society for donors who make annual gifts year after year. And I would like to thank the hundreds of NULC regional board volunteers across the country who give their time and energy to help grow our donor community. With your ongoing support, Northwestern will continue to achieve excellence and amplify its service to society. Thank you for joining Mimi and me as NULC members, this year and every year. Best wishes, Morton Schapiro President and Professor 1 PRESIDENT’S MESSAG SEPTEMBER 1 , 2019, THROUGH AUGUST 31, 2020 PRESIDENT’S MESSAGE On behalf of our entire community, I want to express my gratitude to members of the Northwestern University Leadership Circle (NULC) . THE IMPACT OF LEADERSHIP GIVING 2020 2 OVERVIEW The Leadership Circle honors contributors who make cumulative gifts of $1,000 and above during the University’s ﬁscal year, which runs from September 1 through August 31 . Matching gifts from companies and ﬁrms count toward membership.* NULC members can choose from the following levels of giving, each offering a variety of beneﬁts: RECENT UNDERGRADUATE ALUMNI 2020 graduates — $120/ year 2017 2018 , , and 2019 graduates — $240/ year 2012 2016 – graduates — $600/ year MEMBER ($1 000 $2 499/ , – , year ) Access to the NULC Insider Series, exclusive interviews with University leaders and faculty innovators who will answer your questions about Northwestern; stories about the difference your philanthropy makes in the NULC Impact Report; and campus news and updates in Inside the Circle , our email newsletter. ( To receive the newsletter, please update your email address at our.northwestern.edu ) FELLOW ($2 500 $4 999/ , – , year ) All Member beneﬁts plus special communications from the president and trustees and two one-day Evanston campus parking permits by request. SUSTAINER ($5 000 $9 999/ , – , year ) All Fellow beneﬁts plus access to an NULC donor liaison who can answer questions about Northwestern and your giving, networking opportunities with other NULC members, and ﬁve one-day Evanston campus parking permits by request. DEANS’ CIRCLE ($10 000 $24 999/ , – , year ) All Sustainer beneﬁts plus special access to Evanston and Chicago campus facilities and programming, including behind-the-scenes tours at venues such as The Block Museum of Art and Deering Library. PRESIDENT’S CIRCLE ($25 000 $49 999/ , – , year ) All Deans’ Circle beneﬁts plus opportunities to attend events with University leaders. FOUNDERS’ CIRCLE ($50 000 , and above year / ) All President’s Circle beneﬁts plus personal VIP assistance and private campus tours of new buildings and special exhibits. *Matching gift claims count toward membership regardless of when actual corporate funds are received. Claims must be received in the same ﬁscal year as the originating gift to count toward membership. Most NULC members also belong to NU Loyal, which recognizes donors who give to Northwestern for three or more consecutive ﬁscal years. The generosity and commitment of NULC and NU Loyal members help advance the University’s highest priorities. Depending on how a leadership gift is designated, NULC members may also be recognized through the giving societies of a speciﬁc school or unit of the University: AREAS OF GREATEST NEED AND UNDERGRADUATE SCHOLARSHIPS 1851 Society BIENEN SCHOOL OF MUSIC The Lutkin Society THE BLOCK MUSEUM OF ART Block Leadership Circle FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE Nathan Smith Davis Society KELLOGG SCHOOL OF MANAGEMENT Kellogg Leadership Circle ( gifts of $2 500 , and above ) McCORMICK SCHOOL OF ENGINEERING The Walter P. THE IMPACT OF LEADERSHIP GIVING 2020 8 YOUR IMPACT YOUR IMPACT: THRIVING AT NORTHWESTERN Mia Mamone ’ grew up in Noble, Oklahoma, a small 21 town known as the rose rock capital of the world. During a summer leadership program for girls in her home state, she developed a passion for writing and reporting. The experience prompted this high school valedictorian to apply early decision to Northwestern’s Medill School of Journalism, Media, Integrated Marketing Communications. Mamone arrived on campus a few weeks before Wildcat Welcome, as a participant in the Weinberg College of Arts and Sciences’ Bridge program. She says enrolling in Bridge—a free program that helps prepare ﬁrst-generation enroll in Medill’s global reporting course and learn about and/or low-income students for college success by offering arts and culture in London—her ﬁrst international trip. supplementary coursework and workshops—was one of the best decisions she’s ever made. “I got a crash course in critical thinking and journalism, which I wasn’t able to formally study in high school,” she says. “More than anything, I made strong friendships. Some of the people I admire most at Northwestern, I met during Bridge.” The following year, Mamone served as a Bridge counselor and found fulﬁllment helping students from similar backgrounds acclimate to campus life. Pursuing a double major in journalism and gender and sexuality studies, she discovered her home away from home in the Communications Residential College (CRC) and in the newsroom at North by Northwestern , an independent student publication. She has also taken on leadership roles, serving as CRC philanthropy chair and editor in chief of North by Northwestern . “Grants and scholarships have helped enhance my Northwestern experience signiﬁcantly,” says Mamone. During her ﬁrst year on campus, for example, a Knight Family Foundation Student Stipend of $1,500 helped offset the cost of necessities like cold-weather gear, school supplies, dorm furnishings, and a plane ticket home for winter break. In 2019, Mamone received the Class of 2007 Scholarship and a grant from the Jeffrey Zucker Medill Student Experience Fund. The grant made it possible for her to In addition, the Summer Internship Grant Program (SIGP) helped cover Mamone’s living expenses while she interned at a public radio station in Oklahoma and an investigative journalism outlet, Oklahoma Watch. When her 2020 summer plans got sidelined by the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, another SIGP grant from The Alumnae of Northwestern University enabled Mamone to continue working as a public relations aide for Northwestern’s Ofﬁce of Global Marketing and Communications. It’s a work-study role she’s held since her ﬁrst year at the University. “I’m so thankful for Northwestern,” says Mamone, who hopes to pursue a career as a multimedia journalist after graduation. “I found that I could get by, and even thrive, in a new environment very far from home.” Northwestern provided $195 million in ﬁnancial aid to undergraduate students in 2019–20. 2,644 awards have been made to undergraduate students through the Summer Internship Grant Program since 2007 .

” We are building strong relationships between our alumni, students, and local businesses that will last well beyond the pandemic. ” PROFESSOR LINDA DARRAGH

professional mentors and experts work with student entrepreneurs. YOUR IMPACT: INVESTING IN INNOVATION One lesson Professor Linda Darragh has learned in 30 years of working with business innovators is that entrepreneurship can take many paths. If you’re a Northwestern student with a hot idea, you might launch a startup. If you’ve had a successful career at a growing company, you might leave to help build a brand-new venture. Many business owners got a crash course in entrepreneurship in 2020 , when the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic hit and they sought to protect the health of their employees and customers and stay afloat financially. At Northwestern’s Kellogg School of Management, Darragh connects students, faculty, and alumni with startups and small businesses in her role as a clinical professor of entrepreneurship and the Larry Levy Executive Director of the Kellogg Innovation and Entrepreneurship Initiative. Those efforts took a new turn when she spoke with Timothy Feddersen, the Wendell Hobbs Professor of Managerial Politics at Kellogg, a member of the City of Evanston’s COVID-19 task force. Both professors knew that local businesses faced significant challenges and believed the Kellogg community could help. In May 2020 , they launched the Kellogg Small Business Advisory Initiative, through which alumni and students provide pro bono consulting to Evanston business owners in areas from digital marketing to financial planning. By mid-September, nearly 150 users had signed up online for the program. Community members can browse the Kellogg network of volunteers across functions and industries, scheduling meetings to discuss their business challenges. “We are building strong relationships between our alumni, students, and local businesses that will last well beyond the pandemic,” Darragh says. About 60 alumni and students have joined the initiative as mentors. During this challenging year, Kellogg donors also contributed $1.2 million to the school’s Student Assistance Fund, which awarded more than 500 internship stipends and hardship grants to students with financial need. And Darragh says alumni around the world offered enthusiastic support to VentureCat, Northwestern’s annual student startup competition, which was held online this year. For many years, philanthropic gifts from NULC members have fueled innovation at Kellogg. The Levy Institute for Entrepreneurial Practice, endowed by University Trustee Larry Levy ’ , ’ 66 67 MBA and Carol Levy ’ 64 , provides the foundation for the school’s entrepreneurship curriculum and engagement activities for students. Generous support from Matthew McCall ’ 91 MBA 92 MEM , ’ helps students test business ideas they develop in class. “Programs and faculty are essential in entrepreneurship,” Darragh says. “When students can meet entrepreneurs, test their ideas, and be coached by entrepreneurial faculty, all of a sudden they see this as a pathway and a career opportunity. That’s why gifts to help experiential opportunities thrive at Kellogg are so important.”

” Your support can help give students a voice and a role that we wouldn’t be able to experience otherwise. ” PETE PULEO 19 ’

Northwestern students pursue University-sponsored study or travel abroad in a typical academic year. YOUR IMPACT: GLOBAL ENGAGEMENT Every Northwestern student has their own idea of what makes a global learning experience exciting. For Pete Puleo ’ , who took two summer research trips 19 to the Arctic to study climate change, it was camping with fellow scientists, pulling mud samples from the depths of glacial lakes, and viewing the breathtaking scenery of southern Greenland by helicopter. “It was such an incredible opportunity,” Puleo says. “It’s difficult to put into words how special it was to be in Greenland doing work that I view as really important.” Puleo majored in earth and planetary sciences as a Northwestern undergraduate and is now continuing his studies in the department’s PhD program. He is a member of Associate Professor Yarrow Axford’s research group, which investigates Earth’s climate history primarily by studying Arctic lake sediments. Collected in long tubes (or “cores”), the sediment samples provide a valuable record of past climate that can help predict how the planet will respond to future fluctuations. About 13,000 years ago, ice sheet collapse and meltwater changed how water circulated throughout the Atlantic Ocean. Understanding that event could help scientists anticipate what might happen in the future, Puleo says, “if human emissions continue to go unabated and the climate continues to warm.” Puleo’s interest in climate research was sparked by a first-year seminar in the Weinberg College of Arts and Sciences, but his passion for science began earlier. The valedictorian of his high school in Beaver Dam, Wisconsin, Puleo chose Northwestern both for its earth science and band programs (he played the sousaphone in the Northwestern University Wildcat Marching Band). Financial aid also played a role. Along with federal Pell grants, he says, “I was given work-study and Northwestern grants and scholarships that made attending Northwestern the cheapest option out of all the schools I had applied to. I have been very grateful for that.” Puleo’s global research was supported by a grant from the Institute for Sustainability and Energy at Northwestern and a Herbaly Scholarship, which helped him purchase field gear—boots, outdoor clothing, and other equipment—for Greenland. The Graduate School guarantees a minimum of five years of full funding for all doctoral students. “Especially during the coronavirus pandemic, it’s been nice to have that financial security,” Puleo says. In the future, he hopes to do more international research, traveling to Greenland and possibly locations such as Africa and South America to gather climate records. Long-term, he hopes to pursue an academic career with a strong focus on teaching and science outreach. Grants and scholarships funded by NULC donors “give people like me opportunities to be leaders in our community and our field,” he says. “Your support can help give students a voice and a role that we wouldn’t be able to experience otherwise.”

THE IMPACT OF LEADERSHIP GIVING 2020 14 YOUR IMPACT: FACULTY AT THE FOREFRONT Advancing cardiovascular health and diversity within medicine is what drives Clyde W. Yancy, MD , the Magerstadt Professor at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine. As leading heart specialists, Yancy and his colleagues have positioned the school at the vanguard of both cardiology research and the training of physicians from varied backgrounds to serve diverse communities. Born in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and growing up Black in the Deep South of the 1950 s and 1960 s, Yancy saw ﬁrsthand how a lack of quality medical care and diversity among providers impacted people throughout the region. While disparities were common and still are, his own family physician, Dr. Hall, was an example of how a doctor could improve the health of an entire community. As Yancy started to think about a career in medicine as a way to do as much good as possible for as many people as possible, his mother asked him a simple but potent question, “Why not?” Upon seeing a model of the human heart in medical school at Tulane University, he knew that cardiology was his calling. “The heart was the coolest thing I’d ever seen, and it still is,” Yancy says. Following medical school, Yancy spent years in 20 Texas. He served on the faculty at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center for over years and 17 ascended to the rank of professor of medicine in the heart transplant program. He is the author or coauthor of hundreds of articles, including those on heart failure and disparities in health care. In 2011 , Yancy came to Feinberg as the chief of cardiology. He was drawn to Feinberg, he says, because the school shares his expectation of excellence and has a tradition of philanthropy, which has created patient and physician resources such as the Bluhm Cardiovascular Institute. When the coronavirus (COVID-19) surged in the United States in March 2020 , it became clear that Black Americans were disproportionately affected. Yancy’s more than 20 years of research investigating health disparities gave him insights into the pandemic’s unequal impact on Black communities. His highly cited article “ COVID-19 and African Americans,” published online in the Journal of the American Medical Association in April, has been viewed nearly 120,000 times. The higher infection and death rates of COVID-19 in Black communities highlight the urgent need for action to address health care disparities. As Feinberg’s vice dean for diversity and inclusion since 2015 , Yancy has been instrumental in ensuring that medical students are trained in cultural competencies to better serve patients. He has also been inﬂuential in increasing the number of faculty, students, and residents at Feinberg who come from groups traditionally underrepresented in the profession. Being a leader in academic medicine is a resource- intensive enterprise, says Yancy, who is a member of the NULC and the Nathan Smith Davis Society at Feinberg. The capacity to do research, train a new generation of physicians, and treat patients depends directly on the support of annual leadership donors. “Philanthropy is the fuel of excellence,” he says. “Anything else is just existence.” Northwestern’s Division of Cardiology annually ranks among the top 10 cardiology and heart surgery programs in the nation. For 13 consecutive years, US News and World Report has ranked Feinberg School of Medicine in the top 20 of research- oriented medical schools. YOUR IMPACT
